question: Question_11
sols:
We proceed by induction. The case $\displaystyle N=1$ is easy. For
$\displaystyle N=2$, we have

$\displaystyle (1+a)^{2} = 1 + 2a + a^{2} \equiv 1 + 2a \mod{a^{2}}$

Suppose the claim holds for \emph{N}. Then for $\displaystyle N+1$, we
have

$\displaystyle (1+a)^{N+1} \equiv (1+a)^{N}(1+a) \equiv (1 + Na)(1 + a) \equiv (1 + (N+1)a + Na^{2}) \equiv 1 + (N+1)a \mod{a^{2}}$

and so by mathematical induction we are done.

We can use the binomial theorem to see that

$\displaystyle (1+a)^{N} = \sum_{i=0}^{N} \binom{N}{a} a^{i}(1)^{N-i} \equiv \binom{N}{0} + \binom{N}{1}a +\sum_{i=2}^{N} \binom{N}{a} a^{i}(1)^{N-i}\equiv  1 + Na \mod{a^{2}}$

where all the terms in the right most summation are divisible by
$\displaystyle a^{2}$.
hints: This can be solved either by induction or using the binomial theorem.
